content: The Act titled "Justice Against Sponsors of Terrorism Act" recognizes the serious threat of international terrorism to the United States, its impact on commerce and travel, and the need to address aiding and abetting liability. The purpose of this Act is to allow civil litigants to seek relief in US courts against individuals, entities, or foreign countries that have provided material support to terrorist activities. The United States aims to provide access to the court system for those injured by terrorist attacks within the country. The Act aims to allow civil litigants to seek relief in US courts against individuals, entities, or foreign countries that have supported terrorist activities. It states that foreign states shall not be immune from US court jurisdiction in cases seeking money damages for physical injury, property damage, or death occurring in the United States. Foreign states shall not be immune from US court jurisdiction in cases seeking money damages for physical injury, property damage, or death occurring in the United States due to acts of international terrorism or tortious acts committed by the foreign state or its officials. Nationals of the United States can bring claims against foreign states if they would not be immune under this provision. The Secretary of State can certify good faith discussions for a stay of up to 180 days, extendable upon recertification. The Attorney General can petition the court for extensions of a stay of civil proceedings involving foreign states for up to 180 days. The Secretary of State must recertify good faith discussions for the extension. If any part of the Act is deemed invalid, the rest remains unaffected. The amendments apply to civil actions pending or initiated after the enactment date. The amendments made by this Act apply to civil actions pending or initiated after the enactment date, regardless of the circumstances or persons involved. The effective date of the amendments is specified to include actions arising from injuries on or after September 11, 2001.
